title: 113_hr5432
content: The Act may be cited as the "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" and focuses on improving education in orthotics and prosthetics. The "Wounded Warrior Workforce Enhancement Act" mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to award grants to eligible institutions for establishing or expanding orthotics and prosthetics degree programs, with priority given to those partnering with VA medical centers or clinics. The Department of Veterans Affairs or Department of Defense administers clinics and facilities for clinical rotations. Grants under this section range from $1,000,000 to $1,500,000. The Secretary will issue requests for proposals from eligible institutions annually for two years. Eligible institutions must submit grant applications as required by the Secretary. The grant recipients must demonstrate willingness and ability to participate in a partnership and maintain an accredited orthotics and prosthetics education program. Grant funds can be used for building or expanding orthotics and prosthetics programs, as well as training doctoral candidates in related fields. The grant funds can be used for various purposes in orthotics and prosthetics education programs, including training faculty, salary supplementation, financial aid for students, funding research projects, and renovating buildings for program housing. An eligible institution awarded a grant for orthotics and prosthetics education programs can use funds for equipment, admissions preference for veterans, and a three-year period for fund utilization. Eligible institutions are defined as educational institutions. The term "eligible institution" refers to an educational institution offering an accredited orthotics and prosthetics education program. The term "veteran" is defined as per section 101 of title 38, United States Code. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these programs. Authorized appropriation of $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2014 for the Department of Veterans Affairs, remaining available until September 30, 2016. Unobligated amounts to be returned to the Treasury if not used by the Secretary by the specified date. The Center of Excellence in Orthotic and Prosthetic Education is established. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs awards a grant to establish the Center of Excellence in Orthotic and Prosthetic Education. The Center aims to improve outcomes for veterans, Armed Forces members, and civilians through evidence-based research on necessary knowledge, skills, and training for clinical professionals in orthotics and prosthetics. The Secretary prioritizes grants for institutions willing to collaborate with government agencies or private sector entities to provide resources and support for research at the Center of Excellence in Orthotic and Prosthetic Education. The Secretary will issue a request for proposals for a $5,000,000 grant for orthotics and prosthetic research within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The grant recipient must use the funds to develop an agenda for orthotics. The eligible institution awarded the grant under this section may use the grant amount for a period of five years after the award of the grant. The term "eligible institution" means an educational institution with a robust research program and an accredited orthotics and prosthetics education program. The program must be accredited by the National Commission on Orthotic and Prosthetic Education and recognized in the field. It should have associations with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, a local rehabilitation hospital, and be eligible for a $5,000,000 appropriation for fiscal year 2014.
